bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to James H. Lewis, August 9, 1937

div1.p: Andrus writes in support of bill S.115 granting recognition to Gustaf E. Lambert for his role in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to James H. Lewis, August 9, 1937
div1.opener:
Andrus letter
FROM GUST LAMBERT
8-9-37
Hon. James Hamilton Lewis,
Senate Office Building,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Senator:
div1.p:
I have a letter from Hon. J. Parnell Thomas in which he ad-
vises that your $115 has been adversely reported by a sub-
committee to the whole committee on Military Affairs.

As one of those who volunteered and was given yellow fever
in the course of the Walter Reed experiments, no one can know
better than I the importance of the part played by Gust E.
Lambert.

I feel a deep sense of personal obligation to Lambert for
the extraordinary measures taken by him to assure and expedite
my recovery when I was his patient.

That this man's services to his country have not been officially
recognized and rewarded is not a thing in which those who
know of his achievements can take pride.

Can you suggest any action I may take which would assist
you in obtaining recognition for this man?

Do you think that a petition-signed by all (or most) of
those who volunteered for yellow fever innoculation and who
survive-would be helpful?

I am grateful for what you have done and hope you will con-
tinue your efforts in Lambert's behalf until your legislation
is enacted.

closer.seg: Postscript - Will you send me a copy of S115? - J.H.A.
